channel.title: Forcing the VM to load more than one classes?
channel.description:
This is quite the problem... while creating a bot that loads a remote version of runescape.jar, loads it, and haxes it with a set of accessormethods, I ran into the problem of ClassLoader not being able to load more than one class. RLN explained it better than I can, but it has something to do with two classes or more cross-referencing each without that extra class loaded.
[img]http://id3y.com/shit/well_folks.PNG[/img]
Ignore the eventqueue part, it's just because I'm triggering the class load with a button. Help would be greatly appreciated.

item.title: Forcing the VM to load more than one classes?
item.dc:creator: @White_Castle White Castle
item.description:
@White_Castle wrote:

But ruler, that only gets the listeners assigned to the client, not the instance the client already has (the wrapper object, not the wrapper class). Right :|?

item.title: Forcing the VM to load more than one classes?
item.dc:creator: @ruler ruler
item.description:
@ruler wrote:

[quote=“White Castle, post:10, topic:12179”]Wait soo…

getMethods.length now returns 10, but getFields.length is still 0. The class that contains the MouseListener wrapper object (wb.class in the latest client ver) does have fields (liek 1000, LOL), I checked it with Jackie. What the hell now?

BTW:

wb does implement ud or some other Jagex made interface. Is loadClass grabbing all of the values from the interface class?[br][size=1]Posted at: September 04, 2006, 09:38:12 AM[/size][hr]BTW BTW:

interface ud { }

teh hell?[/quote]
hey try :
theBot.theApplet.getComponentAt(1,1).getListeners(MouseListener.class)[0]

item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

[quote=“ruler, post:3, topic:12179”]well i told you this last time but i dk if tis waht you want hehe

change

			return classloader.defineClass(name);

to:

			//return classloader.defineClass(name);
                         return classloader.loadClass(name);

in
AccessorMethods.java

results:
[02:10:33] Starting Bot…
[02:10:33] Loading instance #1 of RuneScape from in\runescape.jar…
[02:10:38] World #63 loaded successfully.
[02:10:41] 0
[02:10:43] Loading instance #2 of RuneScape from in\runescape.jar…
[02:10:51] World #34 loaded successfully.
[02:11:02] 0
[02:11:02] 0
[02:11:04] Loading instance #3 of RuneScape from in\runescape.jar…
[02:11:09] World #54 loaded successfully.[/quote]

item.source: Forcing the VM to load more than one classes?

item.title: Forcing the VM to load more than one classes?
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

have you tried to use the URLClassLoader using threads

this in an attempt however i cannot get it to work, note this is not an example for rs so i dont get any C&P noobs trying to steal code

public class Test { public void test() { Login login = new Login(validUsername,validPassword); Thread t = new Thread(login); t.setContextClassLoader(new TestClassLoader()); t.run(); 
                Login  login2 = new Login(validUsername2,validPassword2);
                t2 = new Thread(login2);
                t2.setContextClassLoader(new TestClassLoader());                     
                t2.run();
        }

}

class Login implements Runnable
{
private String username;
private String password;

Login (String username,String password)
{
    this.username = username;
    this.password =password;
}

public void run()
{
   
        URL url = null;
        try
        {
             url = new URL("file://applicationwithextraclasses.jar");
        }
        catch(Exception e)
        {
            e.printStackTrace();                
        }
        URL [] urls = new URL[1];
        urls[0] = url;
        URLClassLoader cl = new URLClassLoader(urls);
        
        Class c = cl.loadClass("TestWrapper");                
        
        String [] args = new URL[2];
        urls[0] = username;
        urls[1] = password;            
        Method m = c.getMethod("main",new Class[]{String[].class});          
        m.invoke(null,null);           
}

}

class TestClassLoader extends ClassLoader {

TestClassLoader()
{
    super();
}

}

In another file, we add these to another jar which isn’t part of Main test jar because we dont want it to find it on the classpath
nor in the application.jar

public class TestWrapper
{
public static void main(args []String)
{
LoginManager lm = LoginManager.getInstance();
System.out.println(lm.getClass().getClassLoader());
System.out.println(“Status”+lm.getStatus());
lm.login(args[0],args[1]);

  //... do rest of tasks here not part of junit 
}

}

i gave up on that idea

so i thought this may have some better luck

  1. JUnitTestCases that do not require multithreading.
  2. JUnitTestCases that do require multithreading.
  3. MultiThreadingHelperClasses
  4. ProductionClasses

1 contains 4 on its classpath
2 contains nothing on its classpath, but 3 and 4 need adding to its url classloader.

1 & 2 both extend junit.framework.TestCase, but the difficulty is that classes in 3 cannot extend TestCase, and these are the classes that
are doing the work of the test.

Read full topic
